questions.question: Which type of classification system was given by George Bentham and Joseph Dalton Hooker?
questions.explanation: Bentham and Hooker gave natural classification system for flowering plants based on natural affinities and considering external as well as internal features like anatomy, embryology and phytochemistry. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: Numerical taxonomy is based on:
questions.explanation: Numerical Taxonomy is based on all observable characteristics. Numbers and codes are assigned to all characters and data are processed using computers. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: Cytotaxonomy is based on which of the following?
questions.explanation: Cytotaxonomy is based on cytological information like chromosome number, structure, and behaviour. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: Which taxonomy uses chemical constituents of plants to resolve taxonomic confusions?
questions.explanation: Chemotaxonomy uses the chemical constituents of plants to resolve confusions in classification. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: Algae are characterized as:
questions.explanation: Algae are chlorophyll-bearing, simple, thalloid, autotrophic and largely aquatic organisms. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: In which organisms do algae occur in association?
questions.explanation: Some algae occur in association with fungi (lichen) and animals (e.g., on sloth bear). (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: The most common type of asexual reproduction in algae is through:
questions.explanation: Asexual reproduction in algae is by production of different types of spores, the most common being zoospores which are flagellated (motile). (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: Isogamous reproduction involves fusion of gametes that are:
options: Different in size but similar in structure
One large non-motile and one small motile
questions.explanation: Isogamous reproduction involves fusion of gametes that are similar in size, as in Ulothrix and Spirogyra. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: Oogamous reproduction is seen in:
questions.explanation: Oogamous reproduction (fusion between large non-motile female gamete and smaller motile male gamete) is seen in Volvox and Fucus. (NCERT Page 24)

questions.question: What percentage of total carbon dioxide fixation on earth is carried out by algae?
questions.explanation: At least half of the total carbon dioxide fixation on earth is carried out by algae through photosynthesis. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Agar is obtained from which of the following algae?
questions.explanation: Agar is one of the commercial products obtained from Gelidium and Gracilaria (red algae). It is used to grow microbes and in preparations of ice-creams and jellies. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Algin is a hydrocolloid obtained from:
questions.explanation: Algin is a hydrocolloid (water holding substance) obtained from brown algae. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Chlorella is used as food supplement because it is rich in:
questions.explanation: Chlorella, a unicellular alga rich in proteins, is used as food supplement even by space travellers. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: The green colour of Chlorophyceae is due to dominance of:
questions.explanation: Members of Chlorophyceae are grass green due to the dominance of pigments chlorophyll a and b. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Pyrenoids in green algae contain:
questions.explanation: Pyrenoids are storage bodies located in chloroplasts of green algae. They contain protein besides starch. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: The cell wall of green algae consists of:
questions.explanation: Green algae have a rigid cell wall made of an inner layer of cellulose and an outer layer of pectose. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a green alga?
questions.explanation: Laminaria is a brown alga (Phaeophyceae). Chlamydomonas, Volvox, and Spirogyra are green algae. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Brown algae are found primarily in:
questions.explanation: The members of Phaeophyceae or brown algae are found primarily in marine habitats. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: The brown colour in Phaeophyceae is due to the pigment:
questions.explanation: Brown algae vary in colour from olive green to brown depending upon the amount of xanthophyll pigment fucoxanthin present in them. (NCERT Page 26)

questions.question: Food is stored in brown algae in the form of:
questions.explanation: Food is stored in brown algae as complex carbohydrates in the form of laminarin or mannitol. (NCERT Page 27)

questions.question: The plant body of brown algae is attached to the substratum by:
questions.explanation: The plant body of brown algae is usually attached to the substratum by a holdfast, and has a stalk (stipe) and leaf-like photosynthetic organ (frond). (NCERT Page 27)

questions.question: The zoospores in brown algae are:
options: Biflagellate pear-shaped with unequal laterally attached flagella
questions.explanation: Asexual reproduction in brown algae is by biflagellate zoospores that are pear-shaped and have two unequal laterally attached flagella. (NCERT Page 27)

questions.question: Red algae are called so because of the pigment:
questions.explanation: Red algae are called so because of the predominance of the red pigment r-phycoerythrin in their body. (NCERT Page 27)

questions.question: Food is stored in red algae as:
questions.explanation: Food in red algae is stored as floridean starch which is very similar to amylopectin and glycogen in structure. (NCERT Page 27)

questions.question: Red algae reproduce sexually by:
questions.explanation: Red algae reproduce asexually by non-motile spores and sexually by non-motile gametes. (NCERT Page 27)

questions.question: The flagellar arrangement in green algae is:
questions.explanation: In Chlorophyceae, flagella are 2-8 in number, equal in size, and apically inserted. (NCERT Table 3.1, Page 27)

questions.question: Which class of algae completely lacks flagella?
questions.explanation: Rhodophyceae (red algae) lack flagella completely. Their spores and gametes are non-motile. (NCERT Table 3.1, Page 27)

questions.question: Bryophytes are called 'amphibians of plant kingdom' because:
options: They can live in soil but need water for sexual reproduction
They can live both in water and on land equally
questions.explanation: Bryophytes are called amphibians of the plant kingdom because these plants can live in soil but are dependent on water for sexual reproduction. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: The main plant body of bryophyte is:
questions.explanation: The main plant body of the bryophyte is haploid. It produces gametes, hence is called a gametophyte. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: The male sex organ in bryophytes is called:
questions.explanation: The male sex organ in bryophytes is called antheridium. They produce biflagellate antherozoids. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: The female sex organ in bryophytes is:
questions.explanation: The female sex organ called archegonium is flask-shaped and produces a single egg. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: In bryophytes, the sporophyte is:
options: Attached to gametophyte and derives nourishment from it
questions.explanation: The sporophyte in bryophytes is not free-living but attached to the photosynthetic gametophyte and derives nourishment from it. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: Sphagnum is used as packing material because of its:
questions.explanation: Species of Sphagnum provide peat used as fuel and packing material for trans-shipment of living material because of their capacity to hold water. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: Which organisms are the first to colonise bare rocks?
questions.explanation: Mosses along with lichens are the first organisms to colonise rocks and hence are of great ecological importance. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: The thallus of Marchantia is:
questions.explanation: The plant body of Marchantia is thalloid. The thallus is dorsiventral and closely appressed to the substrate. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: Gemmae in liverworts are:
questions.explanation: Gemmae are green, multicellular, asexual buds which develop in small receptacles called gemma cups. They germinate to form new individuals. (NCERT Page 29)

questions.question: The sporophyte of liverwort is differentiated into:
questions.explanation: The sporophyte of liverwort is differentiated into a foot, seta and capsule. Spores are produced within the capsule after meiosis. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: The first stage in the life cycle of moss is:
questions.explanation: The gametophyte of moss consists of two stages. The first stage is the protonema stage which develops directly from a spore. It is creeping, green, branched and filamentous. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: The leafy stage of moss develops from:
options: Secondary protonema as a lateral bud
questions.explanation: The second stage (leafy stage) develops from the secondary protonema as a lateral bud. It consists of upright, slender axes bearing spirally arranged leaves. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: In mosses, sex organs are produced at the:
questions.explanation: In sexual reproduction, the sex organs antheridia and archegonia are produced at the apex of the leafy shoots. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: Pteridophytes are the first terrestrial plants to possess:
questions.explanation: Evolutionarily, pteridophytes are the first terrestrial plants to possess vascular tissues - xylem and phloem. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: In pteridophytes, the main plant body is:
questions.explanation: In pteridophytes, the main plant body is a sporophyte which is differentiated into true root, stem and leaves with well-differentiated vascular tissues. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: Small leaves in pteridophytes are called:
questions.explanation: The leaves in pteridophyta are small (microphylls) as in Selaginella or large (macrophylls) as in ferns. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: Strobili or cones are formed by:
options: Sporophylls arranged spirally along an axis
questions.explanation: Sporophylls may form distinct compact structures called strobili or cones when arranged spirally along an axis. Examples: Selaginella, Equisetum. (NCERT Page 30)

questions.question: The gametophyte of pteridophytes is called:
questions.explanation: Spores germinate to give rise to inconspicuous, small but multicellular, free-living, mostly photosynthetic thalloid gametophytes called prothallus. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: Plants that produce spores of similar kinds are called:
questions.explanation: In majority of pteridophytes all spores are of similar kinds; such plants are called homosporous. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: Which of the following pteridophytes is heterosporous?
questions.explanation: Genera like Selaginella and Salvinia produce two kinds of spores, macro (large) and micro (small) spores, and are known as heterosporous. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: The development of seed habit is considered an important step in evolution because:
options: Female gametophyte is retained on parent sporophyte and embryo develops within it
questions.explanation: In heterosporous pteridophytes, female gametophytes are retained on parent sporophytes and embryos develop within them. This is a precursor to seed habit. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: Equisetum belongs to the class:
questions.explanation: Pteridophytes are classified into four classes: Psilopsida (Psilotum), Lycopsida (Selaginella, Lycopodium), Sphenopsida (Equisetum) and Pteropsida (ferns). (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: Gymnosperms are plants with:
questions.explanation: In gymnosperms (gymnos: naked, sperma: seeds), ovules are not enclosed by ovary wall. After fertilisation, seeds remain exposed (naked). (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: One of the tallest tree species belonging to gymnosperms is:
questions.explanation: The giant redwood tree Sequoia is one of the tallest tree species among gymnosperms. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: Coralloid roots in Cycas are associated with:
questions.explanation: In Cycas, small specialised roots called coralloid roots are associated with N2-fixing cyanobacteria. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: Mycorrhizal association in roots is found in:
questions.explanation: Roots in some genera like Pinus have fungal association in the form of mycorrhiza. (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: The stems of Cycas are:
questions.explanation: The stems are unbranched (Cycas) or branched (Pinus, Cedrus). (NCERT Page 32)

questions.question: The reduced male gametophyte in gymnosperms is called:
questions.explanation: The microspores develop into a highly reduced male gametophyte confined to limited cells. This reduced gametophyte is called a pollen grain. (NCERT Page 33)

questions.question: In Pinus, male and female cones are borne on:
questions.explanation: The male or female cones or strobili may be borne on the same tree (Pinus). However, in Cycas male cones and megasporophylls are borne on different trees. (NCERT Page 33)

questions.question: The composite structure of nucellus protected by envelopes is called:
questions.explanation: The nucellus is protected by envelopes and the composite structure is called an ovule. (NCERT Page 33)

questions.question: In angiosperms, seeds are:
questions.explanation: In angiosperms or flowering plants, the seeds are enclosed in fruits, unlike gymnosperms where seeds are naked. (NCERT Page 34)

questions.question: The smallest angiosperm is:
questions.explanation: Angiosperms range in size from the smallest Wolffia to tall trees of Eucalyptus (over 100 metres). (NCERT Page 34)

questions.question: Angiosperms are divided into:
questions.explanation: Angiosperms are divided into two classes: the dicotyledons and the monocotyledons. (NCERT Page 34)
